rGCSNx-y5.memHandModelNotes:
Shallow, sluggish waters (NatureServe 2005).

Om exterior buffers were selected for this model, essentially eliminating selected map units. I changed exterior buffers to 60m for flowing and open water types. MJR 15 May 2009.

references.B98CON02SEGP: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
references.B82COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1982. Amphibians and reptiles in Kansas. Second edition. Univ. Kansas Mus. Nat. Hist., Pub. Ed. Ser. 8. xiii + 356 pp.
references.B89DUN01NAUS: Dundee, H. A., and D. A. Rossman. 1989. The amphibians and reptiles of Louisiana. Louisiana State Univ. Press, Baton Rouge.
references.B02ERN01USGP: Ernst, C. H., J. W. Gibbons, and M. E. Dorcas. 2002. Regina. Catalogue of American Amphibians and Reptiles 756:1-4.
references.B90COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1990. Standard common and current scientific names for North American amphibians and reptiles. SSAR Herpetol. Circular No. 19. 41 pp.
references.B87DIX01USGP: Dixon, J. R. 1987. Amphibians and Reptiles of Texas, with keys, taxonomic synopses, bibliography, and distribution maps. Texas A&M University Press, College Station. 434 pp.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
references.B00JOH02USGP: Johnson, T. R. 2000. The amphibians and reptiles of Missouri. Second edition. Missouri Department of Conservation, Jefferson City. 400 pp.
references.B99PHI01USGP: Phillips, C. A., R. A. Brandon, and E. O. Moll. 1999. Field guide to amphibians and reptiles of Illinois. Illinois Natural History Survey Manual 8. 282 pp.
references.B84TEN01NAUS: Tennant, A. 1984. The Snakes of Texas. Texas Monthly Press, Austin, Texas. 561 pp.
references.W12NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.B93COL01USGP: Collins, J. T. 1993. Amphibians and reptiles in Kansas. Third edition, revised. University of Kansas Museum of Natural History, Public Education Series No. 13. 397 pp.
references.B70WEB01NAUS: Webb, R. G. 1970. Reptiles of Oklahoma. University of Oklahoma Press, Norman. 370 pp.
references.B04GIB01USGP: Gibbons, J. W., and M. E. Dorcas. 2004. North American watersnakes: a natural history. University of Oklahoma Press, Norman.  439 pp.
references.B98TEN01USGP: Tennant, A. 1998. A field guide to Texas snakes. Second edition. Gulf Publishing Company, Houston, Texas.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.B61SMI01NAUS: Smith, P. W. 1961. The amphibians and reptiles of Illinois. Illinois Natural History Survey 28:1-298.
references.A01ALF01USGP: Alfaro, M. E., and S. J. Arnold. 2001. Molecular systematics and evolution of Regina and the thamnophiine snakes. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution 21:408-423.
references.B04TRA01USGP: Trauth, S. E., H. W. Robison, and M. V. Plummer. 2004. The amphibians and reptiles of Arkansas. University of Arkansas Press.
references.B03ERN01USGP: Ernst, C. H., and E. M. Ernst. 2003. Snakes of the United States and Canada. Smithsonian Books, Washington, D.C.
references.A92SEI01USGP: Seigel, R. A. 1992. Ecology of a specialized predator: REGINA GRAHAMI in Missouri. J. Herpetol. 26:32-37

habitat_description:
The range extends from Iowa, Illinois, and eastern Nebraska to the Gulf Coast of Texas and Louisiana (Conant and Collins 1991; Dundee and Rossman 1989; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Gibbons and Dorcas 2004; Johnson 2000; Phillips et al. 1999; Trauth et al. 2004; Werler and Dixon 2000).

This species is found in big and medium sized rivers, creeks, and pools. It also occupies shallow waters, forested wetland, herbaceous wetland, scrub-shrub wetland, and riparian habitats. This snake inhabits bayous, pond and lake margins, swamps, sluggish streams, rice fields, roadside ditches, and river-bottom sloughs. Burrowing takes place in or using soil, fallen log, and leaf litter. Other forms of cover include water-edge vegetation, crayfish burrows, and under shore debris (Ernst and Ernst 2003; Gibbons and Dorcas 2004; Johnson 2000; Trauth et al. 2004; Werler and Dixon 2000).


SE-	Vegetation found along various water bodies.
